questions.text: All of the following are associated with atopic dermatitis EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) None of the above

 

Explanation:

 

Signs associated with Atopic Dermatitis.

 

 

Hertogheâ€™s Sign

 

 

  • Dermographism seen in Urticaria is Red Dermographism

  • WHITE Dermographism is seen in Atopic Dermatitis.

 

Dennie Morgan infraorbital fold

 

 

Headlight Sign

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Atopic dermatitis is a multifactorial disease characterized by intense itching, chronic or relapsing eczematous lesions, and a personal or family history of atopic diseases.

  • Recognizing the various signs associated with atopic dermatitis, such as the antenna sign, headlight sign, and Hertoghe's sign, is crucial for diagnosis and management

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Volume 3 Chapter 149 Page No 149.21

Journal: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3505421/

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4470211/

https://www.e-ijd.org/article.asp?issn=0019-5154;year=2021;volume=66;issue=6;spage=707;epage=707;aulast=Ramesh

choices.text: All Eczema is Dermatitis, but not all dermatitis is Eczema
Pruritus is hallmark clinical feature
Nummular Eczema is the other name for Discoid Eczema
Pityriasis Versicolor is a form of Dermatitis & it is associated with Atopy

questions.text: Identify the INCORRECT statement about Dermatitis among the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pityriasis Versicolor is a form of Dermatitis & it is associated with Atopy

 

Option D:

 

  • Pityriasis Alba (NOT versicolor) is a form of dermatitis & it is associated with atopy.
  • Pityriasis Alba is a pattern of dermatitis in which hypopigmentation is the most conspicuous feature.

 

 

  • It is seen in the age group of 3 years till puberty
  • It is often a manifestation of atopic eczema but it is not confined to atopic individuals.

 

Pityriasis versicolor is a fungal infection due to Malassezia globosa. It has no relation to atopy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Dermatitis is an umbrella term, covering many skin conditions associated with inflammation of skin including Eczema, so All eczema is dermatitis, but not all dermatitis is eczema.

 

Option B: The hallmark symptom of eczema is intense pruritus.

 

 

The image below shows eczema.

 

 

Option C: Nummular dermatitis / Nummular eczema / Discoid Eczema presents as a well demarcated coin shaped erythematous plaque with vesicles surrounding it.

 

Common locations involved are:

 

  • Trunk
  • Extensor surfaces of extremities:

 

Men - pretibial areas

 

Women – Dorsal aspects of hand

 

The image below shows nummular dermatitis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

  • Pityriasis Alba (NOT versicolor) is a form of dermatitis & it is associated with atopy.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Volume 2 Chapter 39 Page No 39.1-3, 39.7-8, 39.25

choices.text: Atopic Dermatitis (AD) is the diagnosis
UK refinement of Hanifin & Rajka criteria is used in the diagnosis of AD
It has a Flexural distribution in Infantile Phase
Face is the First Site of involvement of AD in infants

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presented to the dermatology clinic with itchy and hyperpigmented plaques in cubital and popliteal fossa as shown in image. Her personal history reveals a chronic & recurrent course of these lesions; family history is positive for asthma. Identify the FALSE statement related to this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It has a Flexural Distribution in Infantile Phase

 

Option C:

 

  • The image showing Scratch Marks & Excoriations due to Pruritic Lesion at a Flexural Site along with a personal history of chronic & recurrent course & a family history of atopy (Asthma) is suggestive of Atopic Dermatitis (AD) or Atopic Eczema (AE) (Option A)
  • Flexural distribution is seen in Childhood & Adult Phase & Extensor distribution in Infantile Phase.
  • It is a Chronic or chronically relapsing Inflammatory Condition.
  • The first site of involvement in infants with atopic eczema is the face.

 

Atopic eczema can be divided into 3 phases:

 

  1. Infantile
  2. Childhood
  3. Adult

 

 

Atopic eczema infantile variant with face affected

 

 

  • Erythematous papules or papulovesicular lesions, which frequently begin in early childhood, are how it manifests.
  • Later, the lesions develop excoriation and Lichenification. It frequently has a relationship with secondary infections & skin dryness.
  • The UK refinement of Hanifin & Rajka criteria is used in the diagnosis of Atopic dermatitis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: UK refinement of Hanifin & Rajka’s diagnostic criteria of atopic dermatitis (Eczema):

 

  • An itchy skin condition (or parental report of scratching or rubbing in a child)
  • Plus three or more of the following:
  1. Onset below age 2 years (not used if child is under 4 years)
  2. History of skin crease involvement (including cheeks in children under 10 years)
  3. History of a generally dry skin
  4. Personal history of other atopic disease (or history of any atopic disease in a first degree relative in children under 4 years)
  5. Visible flexural dermatitis (or dermatitis of cheeks/forehead and outer limbs in children under 4 years)
     

Clinical features include:

 

  • Dennie morgan fold under lower eyelid
  • Allergic shiners – periorbital pigmentation
  • Allergic salute – horizontal groove on dorsum of nasal bridge
     

Dennie morgan fold

 

 

Complications:

 

  • Staphylococcus aureus is the most common organism to cause secondary infections in the lesions of atopic dermatitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Atopic dermatitis in infants typically involves the face and extensor surfaces rather than flexural areas, which are more commonly affected in older children and adults.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Volume 2 Chapter 41 Page No 41.1, 41.2, 41.13-19

Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Volume 3 Chapter 149 Page No 149.21

questions.text: A Systemic Disease known to be associated with Seborrheic Dermatitis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Parkinson’s disease

 

Option A:

 

  • It is well-documented to be associated with seborrheic dermatitis. Patients with Parkinson’s disease often have an increased prevalence of seborrheic dermatitis, which may be related to the dysregulation of autonomic functions that affect the sebaceous glands.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. COPD (Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease)

 

  • It is a lung disease characterized by chronic obstruction of lung airflow that interferes with normal breathing.
  • There is no direct association between COPD and seborrheic dermatitis.

 

Option C. Multiple myeloma

 

  • It is a cancer of plasma cells.
  • While it can cause a variety of systemic symptoms, it is not typically associated with seborrheic dermatitis.

 

Option D. Leprosy

 

  • It is a chronic infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae, affecting the skin and peripheral nerves.
  • It is not commonly associated with seborrheic dermatitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Seborrheic dermatitis is commonly associated with Parkinson’s disease due to possible autonomic dysregulation affecting the skin, particularly the sebaceous glands.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Volume 2 Chapter 40 Page No 40.1-40.4

choices.text: Berloque Dermatitis is due to Perfumes
Meyerson Nevus is also known as Halo Dermatitis
Esteatotic eczema is also called as Eczema Craquele
Lymphomas are most common cause for Erythroderma

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lymphomas are most common cause for Erythroderma

 

Option D: Erythroderma / Exfoliative dermatitis is an inflammatory skin disease affecting > 90% of body surface.

 

 

The most common causes of erythroderma in decreasing order of frequency are:

 

  • Eczema (40%)
  • Psoriasis
  • Lymphoma &Leukaemia

 

Pityriasis rosea is not a cause of erythroderma.

 

  • The most common cause of erythroderma is Eczema (NOT lymphoma)

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Berloque Dermatitis

 

  • This is caused by exposure to certain chemicals found in perfumes. The chemicals, primarily bergapten, are photosensitizing agents that can cause a rash on areas of the skin exposed to the perfume and then to sunlight.

 

 

Option B. Meyerson Nevus, or Halo Dermatitis

 

  • This is a benign skin condition where an Eczematous Halo develops around a Mole (Nevus). This is a correct association.

 

 

Option C. Eczema Craquele / Asteatotic Eczema:

 

  • Itusually develops in the elderly.
  • It affects the legs, arms & hands of elderly people in the context of very dry skin.

 

 

  • The illness is typically chronic, relapsing in the winter and going away in the summer, but it eventually becomes irreversible.
  • It might be a presenting symptom in myxoedema. It might also be brought on by a lack of zinc.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most common cause of Erythroderma is Eczema, not lymphomas. Lymphomas may cause erythroderma, but they are not the most frequent cause.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 39 Page No 39.10, 39.25, 39.31, Chapter 88 Page No 88.29

Online resource: https://www.uptodate.com/contents/erythroderma-in adults#:~:text=Erythroderma%20(literally%2C%20%22red%20skin

choices.text: Mono Benzyl Ether of Hydroquinone (MBEH)

questions.text: A woman who is a regular user of hair dye presented as shown in the image below. What is the allergen responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Paraphenylene Diamine (PPD)

 

Option B:

 

  • It is a common allergen found in permanent hair dyes.
  • It is well-known to cause allergic contact dermatitis, which can present with symptoms like those described in the patient's presentation.
  • Allergic contact dermatitis is an inflammatory response to an allergen that only manifests as an eruption in people who have already been sensitive to the allergen.
  • It is a type IV delayed hypersensitivity.
  • The diagnosis is made by Patch test

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Para-tertiary Butyl Phenol (PTBP)

 

  • It is less commonly used in hair dyes and is not the most frequent cause of allergic contact dermatitis related to hair dye use.

 

Option C. Nickel

 

  • It is a common allergen associated with jewellery and metal closures on clothing but is not typically found in hair dye products.

 

Option D. Mono Benzyl Ether of Hydroquinone (MBEH)

 

  • It is used in skin lightening creams and is not a common ingredient in hair dyes.

 

Substances & the allergens in them causing ACD

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Para-Phenylene Diamine (PPD) is a common allergen in hair dyes that can cause allergic contact dermatitis, presenting with an erythematous, pruritic, and vesicular rash on areas of application.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 128 Page No 128.74

choices.text: It can be diagnosed with Patch Test
It is a delayed type of Hypersensitivity
Due to Direct Toxic Effects of a strong chemical

questions.text: A 45-year-old person, who is taking care of cleaning utensils at his home since covid lockdown, presents to the dermatology clinic with intensely pruritic lesions for 6 days. History reveals, the lesions began to appear after he recently changed the cleaning detergent. Considering the likely diagnosis, which statement is True about the given condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Due to Direct Toxic Effects of a strong chemical

 

Option D:

 

  • Detergents can cause both ACD and ICD, if MCQ mentions a patient developing dermatitis features while continuing the same detergent, the answer would be ACD, as a delayed response is seen due to the sensitization phase which can be seen in ACD.
  • But, if MCQ mentions that the change in detergent caused the Dermatitis, then the most likely answer would be ICD, due to the irritant substance in the newly changed detergent causing ICD.
  • The given scenario is suggestive of irritant contact dermatitis, which is the skin's reaction to the physical/toxic effects of a wide range of environmental exposures.
  • It is not an immune system-mediated response.
  • Another name for ICD is wear and tear dermatitis.
  • Examples include diaper rash, napkin rash, and eczema in housewives brought on by soaps, detergents, and wet work.

 

Treatment includes avoidance of Irritants, Personal Protection & Barrier Creams.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Irritant contact dermatitis is caused by the direct toxic effect of chemicals on the skin and does not require prior sensitization.
  • It can be differentiated from allergic contact dermatitis by the lack of a requirement for sensitization, immediate onset after exposure, and negative patch testing.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 129 Page No 129.4-8

choices.text: Photo Patch Test is used to diagnose Photoallergic Contact Dermatitis
Gold Standard Diagnostic Test for Airborne Contact Dermatitis (ABCD) is a Patch Test
In Patch Testing, the patch is removed after 48 hours to examine the site of reaction
Patch Test Works on the Principle of Type III Hypersensitivity Reaction

questions.text: Identify the INCORRECT statement from the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Patch Test Works on the Principle of Type III Hypersensitivity Reaction

 

Option D:

 

  • Patch test works on the principle of Type IV hypersensitivity reaction (NOT Type III)
  • Patch testing is a test to detect sensitivity to a specific allergen.
  • A set of suspected allergens is applied to the patients back under occlusive dressings or patches.
  • It is allowed to remain in contact with the skin for 48 hours.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Photo patch test

 

  • This is indeed used to diagnose photoallergic contact dermatitis.
  • This test involves applying a substance to the skin and then exposing the area to ultraviolet light to see if a reaction occurs.

 

Option B. The Gold standard Diagnostic test for Airborne contact dermatitis (ABCD)&Allergic Contact Dermatitis (ACD) is a patch test.

 

The image below shows a patch test.

 

 

Option C. After the patch is removed, the area is examined for Type IV /delayed type of hypersensitivity.

 

  • 48 hours: patch removal for initial reading to detect delayed hypersensitivity reaction
  • 72-96 hours: final reading done for confirmation

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Patch tests are used to diagnose Allergic contact dermatitis and work on the principle of a Type IV hypersensitivity reaction, which is T cell-mediated and does not involve immune complex deposition as seen in Type III hypersensitivity.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Volume I Chapter 4 Page No 4.23

Fitzpatrick’s Dermatology 9th Edition Page No 406

Online resources: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3900336/

choices.text: Wheals are seen in Urticaria & they are Evanescent Lesions
Most of the times cause is not known
Darier's Sign is seen in Urticaria

questions.text: All of the following are characteristics of Acute Spontaneous urticaria EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Darierâ€™s Sign is seen in Urticaria

 

Option C:

 

  • Darier's sign refers to the appearance of a wheal after stroking the lesional skin and is a diagnostic feature of mastocytosis, not urticaria.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Wheals are the hallmark of urticaria and are characterized by transient, elevated, and often itchy swellings of the skin, which are indeed evanescent, meaning they typically resolve within hours.

 

Option B. It is true that in many cases of acute spontaneous urticaria, the cause is not known, making this condition idiopathic in nature.

 

Option D. Urticaria usually subsides without leaving pigmentation, as it does not involve the deeper skin layers where pigment cells are located, which is a characteristic feature of this condition.

 

Urticaria and Mastocytosis:

While both conditions involve mast cells, urticaria is a hypersensitivity reaction (IgE-mediated or non-IgE), whereas urticaria pigmentosa is a form of mastocytosis, involving increased mast cell proliferation in the skin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Darier's sign, which is the rapid appearance of a wheal after stroking the lesional skin, is associated with mastocytosis and not acute spontaneous urticaria.

  • Urticaria is characterized by evanescent wheals that often have an idiopathic cause and resolve without pigmentation.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II-9th Edition Chapter 42, Page no 42.1-4, 42.8-10

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4thEdition Page No 309

choices.text: Pseudodariers Sign & Smooth Muscle Hamartoma

questions.text: A child presented with multiple blemishes and light brown macules located on the trunk as shown in the below image. On scratching of lesions, erythema develops around the lesion which is known as _____ & seen in______?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Darier's Sign & Urticaria Pigmentosa

 

Option D. Darier's sign in urticaria pigmentosa (a form of cutaneous mastocytosis)

 

  • This involves the development of erythema and swelling around a lesion upon physical irritation such as scratching, due to mast cell degranulation.

 

 

Darier's sign is not specific for mastocytosis as it is also rarely seen in juvenile Xanthogranuloma and acute lymphoblastic leukaemia.

Using a Pen--> A lesion of Cutaneous Mastocytosis is Stroked ---> Histamine is released due to Degeneration of Mast Cell-> Erythema + Urticarial Halo 

 

Treatment includes:

 

  • Avoiding physical stimuli that trigger mast cell degranulation- temperature extremes, pressure, alcohol
  • Antihistamines
  • Mast cell stabilizers
  • Topical and oral corticosteroids
  • PUVA therapy
  • Tyrosine kinase inhibitors like imatinib.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pseudodarier's sign, which is associated with smooth muscle hamartoma, typically manifests as a localized elevation of the skin or "goosebump" appearance when stroked, rather than erythema around the lesion.

 

Option B. Koebner's phenomenon

 

  • This is observed in conditions like lichen planus, psoriasis and vitiligo where new lesions appear at the site of skin trauma.

 

 

  • However, this is different from the erythematous reaction described in the question.

 

Option C. Darier's sign is not associated with Darier's disease (a genetic keratinization disorder).

  • In Darier's disease, skin findings include greasy, scaly papules and plaques in seborrheic areas, not the response described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Darier's sign, characterized by the development of erythema and swelling around a lesion upon scratching, is a diagnostic feature of urticaria pigmentosa, a form of cutaneous mastocytosis.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Chapter 46, Page No 46.1-6

choices.text: C1 Esterase Inhibitor Deficiency can cause it
Presents as Angioedema without Wheals & Itching
Pitting Edema of Face, Lips &Mucous Membranes

questions.text: Which of the following statements about angioneurotic edema is FALSE?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pitting Edema of Face, Lips &Mucous Membranes

 

Option D:

 

  • Angioneurotic edema, or angioedema, is characterized by non-pitting, localized swelling. Unlike typical edema, which is often pitting, angioedema due to fluid leakage into tissues does not retain a pit when pressed.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. C1 esterase inhibitor deficiency is a well-known cause of hereditary angioedema, which leads to recurrent episodes of severe swelling (angioedema). This type of edema is not pitting in nature and is not accompanied by wheals or pruritus (itching).

 

Option B. Angioneurotic edema is indeed also referred to as Quincke’s disease. This is a synonym for angioedema, particularly when it affects the face and lips.

 

 

Option C. Angioedema typically presents as swelling of the deeper dermis and subcutaneous or submucosal tissue, often without wheals and itching, which are characteristic of urticaria (hives).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Angioedema, also known as Angioneurotic Edema or Quincke’s disease, presents as Non-PittingEdema of the Deeper Dermis and Subcutaneous orSubmucosal tissue without wheals or itching and can be caused by C1 Esterase Inhibitor Deficiency.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II- 9th Edition Chapter 43, Page No 43.2

choices.text: History of Atopy might be present in the Family
Indeterminate Leprosy is an important differential for this presentation
It is a Variant of Vitiligo

questions.text: A 6-year-old child came with white lesions over his face as shown in the image below. Which of the following statements is INCORRECT regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It is a Variant of Vitiligo

 

Option D: Based on the information provided and the appearance of the lesions in the image, the diagnosis is most likely Pityriasis Alba, which is a common skin disorder seen in children that causes Hypopigmented, Scaly Patches.

 

  • This statement is incorrect regarding the condition in the image. Pityriasis alba is not a variant of vitiligo.
  • Vitiligo is characterized by the complete absence of melanocytes in the affected area, leading to well-demarcated, white patches (Depigmented lesions), whereas pityriasis alba typically presents with less distinct, more irregular patches that are not completely depigmented.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. History of atopy might be present in the family –

  • Pityriasis alba is often associated with a history of atopic dermatitis or other atopicdiseases, which may have a familial occurrence.

 

Option B. Mostly happens in children –

  • Pityriasis alba predominantly occurs in children and is considered a benign condition that usually resolves with age.

 

Option C. Indeterminate leprosyis an important differential for this presentation –

  • When evaluating hypopigmented lesions, especially in areas where leprosy is endemic, it is crucial to consider leprosy in the differential diagnosis.

 

 

 

 

  • Indeterminate leprosy presents with a single hypopigmented macule and can be a consideration before the disease progresses to more definitive forms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Recognize pityriasis alba as a common cause of hypopigmented lesions in children, which may be confused with other conditions such as vitiligo or indeterminate leprosy.
  • Understanding the clinical presentation and associated conditions, like atopy, is essential for accurate diagnosis and appropriate management.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Page No 39.25, 88.34

choices.text: Family History of Asthma should be inquired
Patch Test should be done to confirm the diagnosis
Flexural Eczema is classical in infants affected with this condition

questions.text: An infant presents with facial eczema as shown in the image below. Which of the following is true statement regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Family History of Asthma should be inquired

 

Option A.

 

  • Atopic dermatitis is part of the atopic triad, which includes Asthma, Allergic Rhinitis, and AD itself.
  • There is often a family history of these atopic conditions, so inquiring about a family history of asthma is relevant and can support the diagnosis of AD.

 

The image appears to show an infant with red, inflamed skin on the face, which is consistent with a presentation of Atopic Dermatitis (AD).

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Improves in winters –

 

  • AD often worsens in the winter due to drier conditions, which can exacerbate the skin dryness and irritation associated with AD.

 

Option C. Patch test should be done to confirm the diagnosis –

 

  • Patch testing is not routinely used to diagnose AD.
  • Instead, AD is usually diagnosed based on clinical criteria (Hanifin Rajka), including a personal or family history of atopy, the presence of typical lesions, and chronic or relapsing dermatitis.

 

Option D. Flexural eczema is classical in infants affected with this condition

 

  • This statement is generally incorrect for infants.
  • While flexural eczema, which affects the bends of elbows, behind the knees, and other folded areas of the skin, is common in older children and adults with AD, infants more commonly have eczema on their face and extensor surfaces like knees & elbows dueto damage of skin barrier function due to trauma by crawling, as shown in the image below.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Atopic dermatitis is a common inflammatory skin condition associated with the atopic triad (eczema, asthma, allergic rhinitis) and can be supported by a family history of these conditions.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Page No 41.17

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4thEdition Page No 208

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with widespread, red, scaly, and flaky skin that covers more than 90% of his body surface area, as depicted in the image. He reports that the rash started on his scalp and has progressively involved his entire body over the past few weeks. He also complains of severe itching and scaling. His medical history is significant for mild dandruff. He denies any recent infections, drug intake, or history of blistering disorders. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Seborrheic Dermatitis

 

Option B: The description given in this case scenario is supportive of the diagnosis of Erythroderma / Exfoliative dermatitis.

 

Erythroderma / Exfoliative dermatitis:

 

  • It is a severe and potentially life-threatening skin disorder characterized by widespread redness and scaling of the skin.

 

Causes of Erythroderma / Exfoliative dermatitis:

 

 

  • In this question, case scenario of a patient with a history of dandruff and widespread erythematous, scaly, and flaky skin, particularly starting on the scalp and progression to cover a significant area of the body is suggestive of SEBORRHEIC DERMATITIS.
  • SEBORRHEIC DERMATITIS can present with erythroderma, especially in severe cases.
  • Seborrheic dermatitis often starts with flaky, yellow greasy scaly skin on the scalp (dandruff) and can spread to other seborrheic areas like:
  1. Scalp
  2. Forehead
  3. Eyebrows
  4. Eyelids (along the Lash Line)
  5. Nasolabial Folds (the lines from the Nose to the Corners of the Mouth)
  6. External Ear Canals
  7. Postauricular (behind the Ears) Areas
  8. Sternum (Middle of the Chest)

 

 

Seborrheic dermatitis presenting with yellow greasy scaly skin over face in a child is depicted in the above image.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pemphigus vulgaris

 

  • Pemphigus vulgaris is a blistering autoimmune disorder characterized by intraepidermal blisters and erosions but is not typically associated with the widespread erythematous and scaling rash seen in the patient.

 

Option C. Stevens-Johnson Syndrome

 

  • SJS is an acute and severe mucocutaneous reaction, usually to drugs, characterized by blistering and epidermal detachment resembling burns, mucosal involvement, and systemic symptoms, which is not consistent with the gradual progression and symptoms described.

 

Option D. Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis

 

  • TEN is a more severe form of SJS with extensive detachment of the epidermis and mucous membranes, high mortality, and is typically drug-induced.
  • The clinical picture described does not include the acute, severe blistering or systemic symptoms typical of TEN.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Diagnose seborrheic dermatitis when presented with a patient with a history of dandruff and widespread erythematous, scaly, and flaky skin, particularly when it starts on the scalp and progresses to cover a significant area of the body.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Page No 39.31

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4thEdition Page No 208

questions.text: Match the Eczemas in Column A with the characteristic features given in Column B:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-c, 2-a, 3-d, 4-b

 

Correct matches:

 

 

1-c: Hair Dye Dermatitis is commonly caused by an allergic reaction to Paraphenylenediamine (PPD), a chemical found in many hair dyes.

 

 

Hair Dye Dermatitis is depicted in the above image.


2-A: Atopic Dermatitis is associated with a variety of complications, including ocular changes such as Anterior-Subcapsular Cataract, Keratoconus & Recurrent Conjunctivitis.
 

3-D: Irritant Contact Dermatitis does not involve a sensitization phase; rather, it is a non-immunologic response to direct chemical injury to the skin.

 

 

4-B: Bindi dermatitis, caused by the adhesive (PTBP-Paratertiary Butylphenol) in bindis, often involves allergic contact dermatitis, which can be confirmed with a patch test.

 

 

Bindi Dermatitis is depicted in the above image.

 

  • Nickel is the most common metal causing Allergic Contact Dermatitis (ACD).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Patch tests are used to diagnose allergic contact dermatitis, not atopic dermatitis (which is instead associated with subcapsular cataract and Keratoconus).
  • Sensitization phase is absent in irritant contact dermatitis, not in bindi dermatitis, which is typically an allergic reaction confirmed by patch testing.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Page No 41.20, 128.51, 129.3

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4thEdition Page No 208, 262, 1109

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient presents with chronic, itchy, and erythematous rashes on his lower legs and feet, as shown in the image. He reports that the rashes often weep and have developed over areas where he feels a heavy sensation after standing for long periods. His medical history is significant for varicose veins and deep vein thrombosis. On examination, there is pitting edema around the ankles and hyperpigmentation of the affected skin. What is the most likely cause of the eczematous changes in this patient's lower extremities?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Venous Insufficiency

 

Option D:

 

Venous insufficiency

 

  • The patient's history and clinical features, including varicose veins, pitting edema, and hyperpigmentation, are characteristic of venous insufficiency, which can lead to Stasis Eczema / Dermatitis (also known as venous eczema).
  • This condition results from poor venous blood flow and increased venous pressure, causing fluid to leak into the surrounding tissues, resulting in inflammation and eczematous changes.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Atopy - Incorrect.

 

  • While atopy refers to the genetictendency to develop allergic diseases and can lead to atopic dermatitis, the patient's presentation is more consistent with stasis eczema due to underlying venous insufficiency, not atopy.


Option B. Drugs - Incorrect.

 

  • Drug reactions can cause various skin changes, including rashes, but the patient's symptoms and signs are more suggestive of a chronic process related to venous insufficiency rather than a drug-induced cause.


Option C. Leather shoes - Incorrect.

 

  • Contact dermatitis can be caused by leather shoes due to allergens like chromates; however, the distribution and chronicity of the rash, along with the patient's history, support a diagnosis of stasis eczema due to venous insufficiency rather than an external allergen like leather.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The clinical presentation of stasis eczema is a result of chronic venous insufficiency.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Page No 39.19

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4thEdition Page No 236

choices.text: Perform Patch Test to confirm the Diagnosis

questions.text: A 40-year-old male construction worker presents with itchy, red, and weeping plaques on his palms and forearms, as depicted in the image. He reports that the rash developed shortly after he started working with wet cement on a new project. He denies any known allergies or atopic history. On examination, the skin lesions are erythematous, with vesicles and some crusting, localized to areas of contact with cement. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Start with Steroids

 

Option D:

 

  • The presentation is suggestive of Allergic contact dermatitis, commonly seen with cement due to the presence of substances like chromium (Potassium Dichromate).

 

 

 

  • Topical steroids are the mainstay of treatment for acute inflammatory dermatitis to reduce inflammation and itching.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Check IgE levels - Incorrect.

 

  • Elevated IgE levels are associated with atopic dermatitis and allergies, but this does not have any role in management of the given patient.

 

Option B. Perform patch test to confirm the diagnosis - Incorrect.

 

  • While a patch test is useful in identifying specific allergens in allergic contact dermatitis, the immediate management should focus on alleviating the patient's symptoms and preventing further skin damage.
  • Patch test should NOT be performed when active lesions are present.

 

Option C. Start with Antihistamines - Incorrect.

 

  • Antihistamines can be used to alleviate itching but do NOT address the underlying inflammation, which is the primary pathology in contact dermatitis. Therefore, steroids are more appropriate for initial management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The management of contact dermatitis, particularly in occupational settings like construction work where cement exposure is common.
  • Treatment with topical steroids should be initiated to reduce inflammation and provide symptomatic relief.
  • Medical students should be aware that while patch testing is useful for diagnosis, the immediate treatment of the dermatitis should NOT be delayed for testing.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Page No 128.22, 128.41

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4thEdition Page No 243, 254

Online resources: https://dermnetnz.org/topics/irritant-contact-dermatitis

choices.text: Underlying principle is a Cell-Mediated Immunity
It is associated with severe burning rather than Itching
Memory T Cells are involved
Patch Test can confirm the diagnosis once the Acute Phase is managed

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presents to the ENT outpatient department for a routine dressing. Shortly after the dressing is applied, he develops an erythematous and oozing reaction around his ear, as shown in the accompanying image. The patient denies previous similar reactions. The dressing material contained povidone-iodine, which the patient has been exposed for the first time now. What is TRUE about the patient's reaction to the dressing change?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is associated with severe burning rather than Itching

 

Option B:

 

  • The patient's symptoms are consistent with irritant contact dermatitis (ICD), which is a non-allergic reaction to a chemical irritant, in this case, povidone-iodine. ICD is characterized more by a burning sensation rather than itching, which is more typical of allergic contact dermatitis (ACD).

 

 

Explanation:


Option A. The underlying principle is cell-mediated immunity - Incorrect.

 

  • This would be true for allergic contact dermatitis, not irritant contact dermatitis, which is a non-immune direct toxic effect of the irritant on the skin.

 

Option C. Memory T cells are involved - Incorrect.

 

  • Memory T cells are involved in allergic reactions, not in the non-immunologic reactions of ICD.

 

Option D. Patch testing can confirm the diagnosis once the acute phase is managed - Incorrect.

 

  • Patch testing is used to diagnose allergic contact dermatitis, not ICD.
  • However, it may still be used if an allergic component is suspected after the acute phase of ICD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • To distinguish between irritant contact dermatitis and allergic contact dermatitis based on symptoms and underlying mechanisms. ICD is characterized by a burning sensation and results from direct toxicity, not an immune-mediated response.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Page No 129.3

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4thEdition Page No 268

choices.text: Urgent Referral for Excision of the Mole
Immediate Full Blood Count and Biochemistry Panel
Prescribe a Potent Topical Steroid for the Eczematous Halo

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presents to the dermatology clinic with a six-month history of multiple asymptomatic, pigmented moles over his trunk and limbs. He also mentions a recent change in one of the moles, which now has a reddish halo and very mild itching around it. There is no history of similar skin changes in the family, and he denies any systemic symptoms. On examination, the mole is 3 mm in diameter with a symmetrical border, uniform color, and an erythematous, eczematous halo surrounding it as shown in the image below. There is no palpable lymphadenopathy, and the rest of the skin examination is unremarkable. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reassurance and Routine Follow-Up

 

Option B:

 

  • The description is consistent with the Meyerson phenomenon, which is a benign dermatological condition where an eczematous halo develops around a nevus (mole).
  • This is not indicative of malignancy, and the moles themselves do not require excision unless there are other suspicious features or changes suggestive of melanoma.
  • Routine follow-up is appropriate to monitor for any changes in the moles.

 

 

Explanation:


Option A. Urgent referral for excision of the mole - Incorrect.

 

  • The urgent excision would be indicated if there were signs suggestive of melanoma, which are not present in this scenario.
     

Option C. Immediate full blood count and biochemistry panel - Incorrect.

 

  • There is no indication from the history or clinical findings that suggest systemic disease; therefore, these tests are not warranted.
     

Option D. Prescribe a potent topical steroid for the eczematous halo - Incorrect.

 

  • While topical steroids could be used to treat the eczematous halo if symptomatic, the most appropriate next step is reassurance and routine follow-up, as the Meyerson phenomenon is benign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Meyerson phenomenon, a benign reaction characterized by an eczematous halo around a nevus, and to understand that reassurance and routine dermatological follow-up are appropriate management.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Page No 39.27

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4thEdition Page No 566

Online resources: https://ijdvl.com/phenomena-in-dermatology/

questions.text: After administering the patch test to a 10-year-old boy with a history of allergic contact dermatitis, when should you schedule his return for patch removal?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 48 hours

 

Option C: The Gold standard Diagnostic test for Airborne Contact Dermatitis (ABCD) & Allergic Contact Dermatitis (ACD) is a patch test.

 

Patch testing:

 

  • It is a method used to determine if a specific substance causes allergic inflammation of a patient's skin.
  • It is typically indicated for patients with suspected allergic contact dermatitis.
  • The test involves the application of various substances in small chambers or patches to the skin, usually on the back.
  • After the application of a patch test, the patches are generally removed at 48 hours (2 days), and an initial reading is taken.
  • This timeframe allows for the elicitation of a Type IV or delayed-type hypersensitivity reaction, which is the basis of allergic contact dermatitis.
  • However, readings at 48 hours may not be sufficient to detect all reactions, and thus an additional reading at 96 hours is often recommended.
  • The additional reading helps to identify late reactions, which could otherwise be missed if only the 48-hour reading is considered.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. 24 hours

 

  • This time frame is too short for most delayed-type hypersensitivity reactions to occur.
  • Removing the patches at 24 hours would likely result in missing many positive reactions.

 

Option B. 72 hours –

 

  • It is not typically when the patches are first removed.
  • The patches are usually removed at 48 hours, and the skin is then inspected for any reactions.

 

Option D. 96 hours

  • This is a common time for a follow-up reading and not the initial removal of the patches.
  • Some protocols suggest readings at this time to ensure that late-appearing reactions are not missed.

 

The image below shows a patch test:

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patch testing, the patch is removed after 48 hours to examine the site of reaction.

 

  • 48 hours: Patch removal for initial reading to detect early hypersensitivity reactions
  • 72-96 hours: Final reading done for confirmation and for detecting late reactions.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition Volume I Chapter 4 Page No 4.23

Fitzpatrick’s Dermatology 9thEdition Page No 406

Online resources: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3900336/

choices.text: Vesicular Lesions due to Herpes Simplex Infection

questions.text: Topical Steroids are most effective in:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Eczematous Dermatitis

 

Option B: Topical steroids are the drug of choice in the treatment of eczematous dermatitis.

 

  • Topical steroids are anti-inflammatory medications that are highly effective in treating eczematous dermatitis, which is characterized by inflammation, redness, and itching of the skin.
  • They work by reducing inflammation and suppressing the immune response in the skin.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Dermal atrophy

 

  • Dermal atrophy is actually a side effect of prolonged or inappropriate use of topical steroids, not a condition that is treated with them.
  • It is thinning of the skin which can lead to transparency, easy bruising, and other skin changes as shown below.

 

 

Option C. Vesicular lesions due to Herpes simplex infection

 

  • Topical steroids are contraindicated in herpes simplex infections because they can exacerbate the condition by suppressing the local immune response, which is necessary to control viral infections.

 

 

Herpes labialis: Vesicular lesions due to Herpes simplex

 

Option D. Rosacea

 

  • Topical steroids may temporarily reduce inflammation associated with rosacea, but their use is generally avoided as they can lead to a worsening of the condition over time, particularly by exacerbating flushing and potentially leading to a condition known as steroid-induced rosacea.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Topical steroids are effective in treating eczematous dermatitis due to their anti-inflammatory properties, but they should not be used for conditions like herpes simplex infections or rosacea and can cause dermal atrophy if used inappropriately.

 

Ref: Fitzpatrick’s Dermatology, 9thEdition Page Number 377

questions.text: The possible diagnosis for a child whose mother had a history of bronchial asthma & child developed itchy plaques bilaterally over the popliteal fossa, & cubital fossa (as shown below) could be?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Atopic Dermatitis

 

Option A: The image displays a child, with scratch marks and excoriations from itchy plaques over the popliteal and cubital fossae, with a maternal history of bronchial asthma indicative of Atopic dermatitis (or eczema).

 

  • This chronic inflammatory skin condition often occurs in families with atopy, encompassing asthma, hay fever, and allergic rhinitis.
  • The patient's personal history reveals a chronic and recurrent course of this condition.
  • In infants, the first site of involvement is often the face.
  • Flexural distribution is observed in both the childhood and adult phases of the condition, while in the infantile phase, extensor distribution is more typical.

 

Atopic eczema can be divided into 3 phases:

 

  • Infantile
  • Childhood
  • Adult

 

 

Atopic eczema infantile variant with face affected:

 

 

  • Atopic dermatitis typically presents with erythematous papules or papulovesicular lesions, often appearing in early childhood.
  • As the condition progresses, the lesions may evolve into excoriated and lichenified areas.
  • Atopic dermatitis is commonly associated with secondary infections and skin dryness.
  • In the diagnosis of atopic dermatitis, the UK refinement of the Hanifin & Rajka criteria is employed.

 

UK refinement of Hanifin & Rajka’s diagnostic criteria of atopic dermatitis (Eczema).

 

  • An itchy skin condition (or parental report of scratching or rubbing in a child)
  • Plus, three or more of the following
    • Onset below age 2 years (not used if child is under 4 years)
    • History of skin crease involvement (including cheeks in children under 10 years)
    • History of a generally dry skin
  • Personal history of other atopic disease (or history of any topic disease in a first degree relative in children under 4 years)
  • Visible flexural dermatitis (or dermatitis of cheeks/ forehead and outer limbs in children under 4 years)

 

Clinical features include:

 

  • Dennie-morgan fold under lower eyelid
  • Allergic shiners – periorbital pigmentation
  • Allergic salute – horizontal groove on dorsum of nasal bridge

 

 

Fig: Dennie-morgan fold

 

Complications: Staphylococcus aureus is the most common organism to cause secondary infections in the lesions of atopic dermatitis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Dermatitis Herpetiformis:

 

  • It is frequently observed in individuals in their 40s.
  • This is an intensely pruritic condition predominantly affecting extensor surfaces of the body, rather than the flexures and associated with gluten sensitivity and is characterized by grouped vesicles on an erythematous base. It is not related to a history of atopy.

 

Option C. Pemphigus Vegetans:

 

  • A variant of pemphigus vulgaris, pemphigus vegetans presents with vegetating plaques, usually in the intertriginous areas.
  • It is not associated with a familial history of atopy and does not predominantly affect the popliteal and cubital fossae.

 

Option D. Psoriasis:

 

  • Psoriasis is a chronic autoimmune skin condition characterized by well-demarcated, scaly plaques.
  • While psoriasis can affect any area of the body but more commonly extensor involvement is seen, it does not typically present as pruritic plaques in the popliteal and cubital fossae in association with a history of atopy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A child with a familial history of atopy presenting with itchy plaques over the popliteal and cubital fossae is most likely suffering from atopic dermatitis.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Volume 2 Chapter 41 Page No 41.1, 41.2, 41.13-19,

Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Volume 3 Chapter 149 Page No 149.21

Image source: https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Category:Atopic_dermatitis

choices.text: Documents Delayed type of Hypersensitivity Reaction

questions.text:
Case scenario: 

 

A 45-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a two-week history of itchy, red, scaly patches on her hands. She reports that she has been using a new brand of hand lotion since 2 weeks. Physical examination reveals erythematous, lichenified plaques on the dorsal aspects of both hands. She has no significant medical history and is currently not taking any medications.

 

Question:


The dermatologist decides to perform an investigation to determine the cause of the patient's contact dermatitis. Which of the following statements is CORRECT regarding the investigation likely to be used in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Option D: All of the above

 

  • The patch test is the correct investigation to determine the cause of allergic contact dermatitis.

  • It documents a delayed-type (Type IV) hypersensitivity reaction, which is the immunological basis for ACD.

  • A panel of allergens is applied to the skin, typically on the back, and observed for reactions over several days, which if present, confirms sensitization to the specific allergen.

 

Gell and Coombs classification of Hypersensitivity reactions important in dermatology

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Documents Delayed type of hypersensitivity reaction - Correct.

 

  • The patch test identifies delayed-type hypersensitivity reactions to specific allergens, which are mediated by T-cells and occur hours to days after exposure.

 

Option B. Investigation of choice in ACD - Correct.

 

  • The patch test is the standard method for identifying the causative allergen(s) in ACD, helping to establish the diagnosis.

 

Option C. Documents Type 4 hypersensitivity reaction - Correct.

 

  • Type 4 hypersensitivity is a delayed-type reaction mediated by T-cells, which the patch test is designed to document.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The patch test is used to document Type 4 hypersensitivity reactions and is the investigation of choice for diagnosing allergic contact dermatitis.

  • It is an important tool for medical students to be familiar with, as it assists in identifying the specific allergens responsible for a patient's dermatitis, which is crucial for effective management and prevention of recurrence.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 128.64

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a skin condition that has been present for several months. She reports that whenever she scratches her skin, even lightly, she develops raised, red lines that are itchy and last for about 30 minutes to an hour. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dermatographic Urticaria

 

OptionC:

 

  • Dermatographic urticaria, also known as skin writing, is characterized by the rapid onset of pruritic, erythematous, raised lines or welts on the skin following minor physical trauma, such as scratching.
  • The lesions typically resolve within an hour.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Contact Dermatitis:

 

  • This condition usually presents with red, itchy rashes at the site of contact with an irritant or allergen.
  • However, it does not typically produce raised lines or welts that appear and disappear so quickly after scratching.

 

Option B. Psoriasis:

 

  • Psoriasis can manifest as raised, red, scaly plaques on the skin.

 

 

  • It does not generally present with rapid onset of transient lines or welts following scratching.

 

Option D. Atopic Dermatitis:

 

  • Also known as eczema, atopic dermatitis typically presents with itchy, red, and inflamed skin.
  • While scratching can worsen the condition, it does not lead to the immediate appearance of raised lines or welts characteristic of Dermatographic urticaria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Dermatographic urticaria is the likely diagnosis in patients who develop transient, raised, red lines on the skin following minor physical trauma such as scratching.
  • This condition is characterized by the appearance of wheals or welts in response to physical stimuli.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II-9th Edition Chapter 42, Page No 42.1-4, 42.8-10

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4thEdition Page No 309
